context: [7] Cell extract incubations were done in 120-ml serum bottles with 10 to 100 Î¼l of crude cell extract, 50 mM TES buffer, 1 to 2 mM ATP, 5 mM sodium sulfide, and 0.2 mM syringate adjusted to a total volume of 1 ml with MilliQ water. [8] The bottles were prepared in an anaerobic cabinet and sealed with gray butyl rubber stoppers. [9] Incubations (25Â°C) were started by addition of syringate, and demethylation activity was monitored by measuring the formation of MT. [1] Analytical techniques.Gas samples were analyzed for H2S, MT, DMS, and methane as described before . [2] Acetate, butyrate, and methanol were measured as described by Cazemier et al. . [3] Methoxylated and hydroxylated aromatic compounds were analyzed by isocratic separation on a high-pressure liquid chromatograph equipped with a Merck LiChrospher 100 RP-18 column and an HP1040 diode array detector. [4] The flow rate of the eluent, 40% (vol/vol) methanol in ammonium phosphate buffer (100 mM, pH 2.6), was 0.5 ml/min.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, Methylsulfanylmethane and methane are both products analyzed during the incubation of cell extracts in anaerobic conditions. The study involves monitoring the formation of methane as a byproduct of demethylation activity, indicating a biochemical relationship where Methylsulfanylmethane may serve as a substrate leading to methane production. However, the specific interactions or mechanisms between the two compounds are not elaborated upon in detail.
